q: is stepping down as CEO of Google, and Larry Page is taking over the company just announced in target="_blank" href="http://investor.google.com/earnings/2010/Q4_google_earnings.html"> its earnings release. Eric Schmidt will become Executive Chairman focused on, deals, partnerships, customers and broader business relationships, government outreach and technology thought leadership, the company says. Google's other cofounder, Sergey Brin will take a more active role in strategic projects including product. The change is effective starting April 4, 2011.

been CEO for nearly a decade. He will now take over as executive chairman. We'll have more for you soon, but in the meantime, here's Eric Schmidt in his own words. When I joined Google in 2001 I never imagined-even in my wildest dreams-that we would get as far, as fast as we have today. Search has quite literally changed people's lives-increasing the collective sum of the world's knowledge and revolutionizing advertising in the process. And our emerging businesses-display, Android, YouTube and Chrome-are on fire. Of course, like any successful organization we've had our fair share of good luck, but the entire team-now over 24,000 Googlers globally-deserves most of the credit. outlook is bright. a fade-away jumper and two free throws in the final 30 seconds that helped secure the win.`` He came up big for us,'' said Carmelo Anthony , who finished with 26 points despite having the flu. He hit some big shots. Allen Iverson gave the Nuggets a 109-108 lead with his jumper with 29 seconds left. Antoine Walker took a jumper with 10.9 seconds, but it was too strong and bounced off a pack of players and out of bounds.

The next step is to reduce U.S. unemployment, an issue Barack Obama should make`` the centerpiece'' of his annual State of the Union address on Jan. 25, the former Cabinet member said. The American people are expecting him to say something about what he's going to do to keep the economy moving forward, Colin Powell said. Colin Powell has criticized his own party in recent months while supporting Barack Obama 's ultimately successful fight for Senate ratification of a new nuclear-arms-reduction treaty with Russia.
